definitions: capable of being used up, eaten, drunk, or destroyed through use
examples: The store sells consumable goods like food and beverages
These batteries are consumable items that need regular replacement

definitions: requiring or using all of someone's time, energy, or attention completely
actively using up or destroying resources, materials, or energy through use
examples: Her consuming passion for art dominated every aspect of life
Writing the novel became a consuming obsession for months
The consuming flames destroyed the entire forest within days
This old car has a consuming appetite for gasoline

definitions: showing the highest degree of skill, accomplishment, or excellence in something
being complete, perfect, or supreme in quality, degree, or extent
examples: She is a consummate professional who handles every situation expertly
The violinist gave a consummate performance at the concert hall
His consummate arrogance made him impossible to work with daily
The merger represented the consummate business deal of the decade

definitions: brought to completion or finalization, especially of an agreement or relationship
made complete or perfect in every detail, quality, or aspect
examples: The consummated deal brought together two major technology companies
Their consummated partnership lasted for over twenty successful years
The consummated artwork displayed the painter's mastery of technique
His consummated skills made him the best surgeon available

definitions: capable of being transmitted from one person to another through direct contact
spreading rapidly from person to person through emotional or social influence
examples: The flu is highly contagious during the winter months
Keep contagious patients isolated from other people in hospital
Her contagious laughter filled the entire room with joy
His contagious enthusiasm motivated the whole team to succeed

definitions: kept or held within certain limits, boundaries, or a specific area
showing self-control, restraint, or composure in behavior or emotional expression
examples: The fire remained contained within the designated burn area
All hazardous materials must be contained in sealed containers
She remained contained despite the shocking news she received
His contained anger was evident only in his clenched fists

definitions: made impure, unclean, or unsuitable by contact with harmful or undesirable substances
examples: The contaminated water supply caused illness throughout the community
Workers must dispose of contaminated materials according to safety protocols

definitions: making something impure, polluted, or harmful by introducing unwanted substances or elements
examples: The contaminating chemicals leaked into the nearby river system
Contaminating bacteria can spread quickly in unsanitary kitchen conditions

definitions: expressing or involving prolonged thought, meditation, or careful consideration of something
devoted to religious or philosophical contemplation, meditation, or quiet thoughtful observation
examples: She sat in contemplative silence while considering her options
The philosopher wrote in a contemplative style about life's meaning
The contemplative monks spent hours in prayer and meditation daily
He chose a contemplative life away from worldly distractions

definitions: existing, occurring, or originating during the same period of time as something else
examples: These contemporaneous accounts provide different perspectives on the historical event
The two artists created contemporaneous works despite living in different countries

definitions: showing or feeling strong dislike, disrespect, or scorn for someone or something considered worthless
examples: She gave a contemptuous look at his poorly prepared presentation
His contemptuous attitude toward authority got him into frequent trouble

definitions: feeling or showing satisfaction with one's possessions, status, or situation in life
examples: The contented cat purred softly while sleeping in the sunshine
She lived a contented life in her small countryside cottage

definitions: causing or likely to cause disagreement, controversy, or heated argument between people
having a tendency to argue, dispute, or engage in controversial discussions frequently
examples: Immigration remains a contentious issue in political debates today
The contentious proposal divided the committee into opposing factions
He's a contentious person who enjoys debating every small point
Their contentious relationship made family gatherings extremely uncomfortable

definitions: disputed, challenged, or competed for by rival parties, groups, or individuals
examples: The contested election results led to demands for a recount
This contested territory has been claimed by both neighboring countries

definitions: relating to or dependent on the context or circumstances in which something exists
examples: The contextual meaning of words can change in different sentences
Historians must consider contextual factors when interpreting ancient texts

definitions: sharing a common border, touching or connected throughout in an unbroken sequence
examples: The United States has forty-eight contiguous states on mainland
These contiguous rooms can be combined for larger conference spaces

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a continent, especially a large landmass
typical of the mainland part of a country as opposed to islands
examples: The continental climate brings hot summers and cold winters here
Continental drift theory explains how Earth's landmasses move slowly
They serve continental breakfast with pastries, fruit, and coffee daily
The continental United States excludes Hawaii and Alaska territories

definitions: dependent on or conditioned by something else happening or being the case
subject to chance, possible but not certain to happen or be true
examples: Her promotion is contingent upon completing the advanced training program
The contract is contingent on approval from the board members
Weather remains a contingent factor in outdoor event planning success
All future projections are contingent and subject to market changes

definitions: happening repeatedly over a period of time but with intervals between occurrences
examples: The continual interruptions made it impossible to concentrate on work
She faced continual challenges throughout her career but never quit

definitions: twisted or bent out of the normal shape in an unnatural or grotesque way
examples: His face was contorted with pain after the injury occurred
The contorted metal showed the tremendous force of the crash

definitions: relating to goods that have been imported, exported, or possessed illegally or against regulations
examples: Guards discovered contraband items hidden in the prisoner's cell yesterday
The ship was carrying contraband weapons across international borders illegally

definitions: serving to prevent pregnancy or conception through various methods or devices used
examples: The doctor discussed various contraceptive options with the patient today
Contraceptive pills must be taken regularly to remain effective always

definitions: made smaller in size, volume, or extent through shrinking or drawing together
bound by or having entered into a formal legal agreement or contract
examples: The contracted muscles caused severe pain in his lower back
Metal becomes contracted when exposed to extremely cold temperatures
The contracted workers must complete the project by December deadline
She contracted services with three different vendors for the event

definitions: relating to or contained within a legally binding agreement between parties involved
examples: All contractual obligations must be fulfilled before project termination occurs
The lawyer reviewed contractual terms to ensure client protection carefully

definitions: containing elements or statements that are opposed to or inconsistent with each other
examples: The witness gave contradictory statements about what happened that night
These contradictory research findings require further investigation to resolve discrepancies

definitions: opposite in nature, direction, or meaning to something else being considered
perversely inclined to disagree or do the opposite of what is expected
examples: The results were contrary to what scientists had predicted initially
Contrary winds forced the sailing ship to change its planned course
She's being contrary just to annoy everyone at the meeting
The contrary child refused to follow any of the simple instructions

definitions: showing striking differences when compared with something else in close association or juxtaposition
examples: The designer used contrasting colors to create visual interest throughout
Their contrasting personalities somehow made them perfect business partners together

definitions: serving to show differences between things through comparison or linguistic analysis methods
examples: Linguists use contrastive analysis to compare different language systems effectively
The contrastive study revealed significant differences between the two cultures

definitions: giving or supplying something as part of a larger whole or cause
examples: Several contributing factors led to the company's financial success recently
All contributing members receive voting rights at the annual meeting

definitions: playing a part in bringing about a result or helping something to happen
examples: Smoking was a contributory factor in his health problems developing
The report identified several contributory causes of the accident yesterday

definitions: deliberately created rather than arising naturally or spontaneously, appearing forced or artificial
examples: The movie's contrived plot made it difficult to enjoy watching
His contrived excuse fooled no one at the important meeting

definitions: capable of being controlled, managed, or kept within desired limits or boundaries
examples: Diabetes is a controllable condition with proper medication and diet
The fire remained controllable thanks to quick action by firefighters

definitions: kept under control, restraint, or within set limits through deliberate management
regulated by rules, laws, or specific conditions that limit access or use
examples: She spoke in a controlled voice despite feeling extremely angry inside
The controlled environment of the laboratory ensures accurate experimental results
This controlled substance requires a prescription from a licensed physician
Access to the controlled area requires special security clearance badges

definitions: exercising restraint, direction, or command over something to manage its operation
having a tendency to dominate or dictate the behavior of other people
examples: The controlling mechanism regulates the temperature inside the greenhouse automatically
She has a controlling interest in three major technology companies
His controlling behavior destroyed many of his personal relationships completely
Nobody likes working for such a controlling and micromanaging boss

definitions: recovering from an illness, medical treatment, or surgery and gradually regaining strength
examples: The convalescent patient needs plenty of rest and proper nutrition
She spent three weeks at a convalescent home after surgery

definitions: fitting in well with a person's needs, activities, or plans without difficulty
occurring at a time that is suitable or opportune for a particular purpose
examples: The convenient location near public transport attracts many tenants here
Online shopping is convenient for people with busy work schedules
The meeting time is convenient for everyone attending from different zones
It's convenient that the bank opens early on Saturday mornings

definitions: coming together from different directions to eventually meet at a common point
examples: Convergent lines meet at a single point in geometric drawings
Their convergent interests in technology brought them together as partners

definitions: familiar with or knowledgeable about something through study, experience, or regular use
examples: She's conversant with several programming languages used in web development
All staff must be conversant with company safety procedures immediately

definitions: having an informal, relaxed style similar to ordinary spoken language between people
examples: The author writes in a conversational tone that engages readers
Her conversational Spanish improved after living in Mexico for months

definitions: having the opposite or reverse relation, position, or characteristics to something else
examples: The converse statement would be equally valid in this mathematical proof
They hold converse opinions on almost every political issue discussed

definitions: capable of being changed from one form, function, or purpose to another
describing a car with a roof that can be folded or removed
examples: This sofa is convertible into a comfortable bed for overnight guests
Convertible bonds can be exchanged for company stock later on
She drives a red convertible with the top down in summer
The convertible's retractable roof makes it perfect for sunny days

definitions: having an outline or surface that curves outward like the exterior of a sphere
examples: The convex mirror provides a wider field of view for drivers
A convex lens focuses light rays to a single focal point

definitions: capable of causing someone to believe that something is true, real, or worthwhile
examples: She gave a convincing argument for changing the company policy immediately
The actor's convincing performance earned him an award nomination yesterday

definitions: extremely complex, intricate, or difficult to follow due to many twists and turns
examples: The convoluted plot made the mystery novel hard to understand
His convoluted explanation only confused the audience even more completely

definitions: prepared for eating by the application of heat through various cooking methods
dishonestly altered, falsified, or manipulated to deceive or mislead others deliberately
examples: The cooked vegetables retain more nutrients than raw ones sometimes
I prefer cooked carrots to raw ones in my salads
The accountant was fired for submitting cooked financial reports yearly
These cooked statistics don't reflect the true situation at all

definitions: willing to help, work with others, or do what is asked without resistance
owned and operated jointly by members who share in benefits and profits
examples: The cooperative students made the teacher's job much easier today
We need a more cooperative approach to solve this complex problem
They live in a cooperative apartment building in downtown Manhattan
The farmers formed a cooperative to market their produce together

definitions: equal in rank, importance, or degree within a system or structure
designed to match or complement each other in color, pattern, or style
examples: The coordinate branches of government provide checks and balances effectively
These coordinate clauses are joined by the conjunction 'and' here
She bought coordinate accessories to match her new dress perfectly
The coordinate bedding set includes sheets, pillowcases, and comforter together

definitions: organized or arranged to work together effectively as a unified whole or system
having the ability to use different parts of the body together smoothly
examples: The coordinated effort of multiple agencies solved the crisis quickly
A coordinated marketing campaign increased sales by forty percent nationwide
The gymnast's coordinated movements impressed all the judges watching today
Children develop coordinated motor skills through play and practice activities

definitions: bringing different elements, people, or activities together to work effectively as one
examples: The coordinating committee oversees all aspects of the annual festival
She excels at coordinating complex projects with multiple team members

definitions: relating to an eighteenth-century English furniture style characterized by graceful outline and ornate carving
examples: The antique Chippendale chairs sold for thousands at the auction
Their dining room features authentic Chippendale furniture from the 1760s
